characters: ON DANCE FLOOR IN NEXT ROOM
IN LINE FOR ROY'S USUAL CHECK-OUT WOMAN 85

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An immaculate pool -- clean, clear and placid -- crowds the back yard, bouncing light against the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pool can be seen THROUGH filigreed metallic blinds. ROY ENTERS FRAME, suited, coffee cup in hand, and peers out at it for a spell. A calming moment to start his day. Then: He raises the blinds, wincing at the floor of sunlight. He checks the window's lock, re-locks it for good measure, then closes the shade again.

dialogues.speaker: AT NEXT WINDOW
dialogues.text: The ritual repeated: blinds up, window's locked, he re- locks it.

dialogues.speaker: AT THIRD
dialogues.text: Repeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three doors line the left wall; one divides the right; all are shut. Roy emerges from the nearest door on the left (a bedroom) and shuts it behind him. He crosses to the single door on the right (a bathroom), opens it, enters, and shuts it behind him. WATER RUNS and a TOILET FLUSHES. He reappears, shuts the door behind him, and enters the middle door on the left (another bedroom, unoccupied). He re-emerges with a handkerchief in hand, then in pocket, and a beeper on his belt, and again shuts the door behind him. He starts for the far door (to a living room) but manages only a few steps before he stops, turns, and heads back to the bathroom door. He opens it and peers inside. A three-count and he shuts it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy rinses out his mug of coffee, washes the sink basin clean of it, wipes down the kitchen countertop, already spotless, and lets the faucet run as -- -- he takes from a cupboard an unlabeled vial of pills. Pulls off the cap, taps two capsules into his palm. And just stares at it. Anxious and exhausted. Then: He tosses the pills down his throat, chases them with tap water, and gives the faucet a firm tug off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Window cracked just enough to suck out his cigarette smoke. AM-FM forecasts the natural weather, region-by- region.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Elsewhere, temperatures in New York in the high 80's, Chicago reports rain, temperatures in the high 70's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy slows to a halt behind a mini-van full of kids. They laugh and scream and wave at Roy. His hands stay glued at 2 and 10.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, it's confirmed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK MERCER, younger than Roy, works the phones. A sea of papers floods his desk, while the adjoining desk (Roy's) is pristine. In lieu of decor there are stacks of cardboard boxes piled everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: -- the Chevy Blazer, the Paris vacation, or the Tiffany necklace. It's okay if you don't remember entering the contest, ma'am, you've won -- The next call -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 3.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: -- do you have a water filtration system in your house? Do you read the papers or watch TV, sir? Then you've probably seen our advertisements -- The next call --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: -- we just have to wait for the sponsor's rep to fly in for the final drawing. That should be next week sometime --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his window, Frank watches Roy, frozen in his car.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: -- if you buy the Waterford II water filtration system, the prize gets recorded as a sales expense and you don't pay any tax. Good deal, huh? Frank turns to one of the boxes marked "Waterford II" and peels off a price sticker: $49.99.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: $398.00 even. You'd pay twice that in stores.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: Roy enters, shuts the door behind him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You want to what? When will he be home? (beat) Mrs. Fisk, my supervisor just stepped into my office and he would love to talk to you. Can you hold just a sec? (puts her on hold; to Roy, overly sunny) Good morning. Something on the radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he offers phone) Irene Fisk. ‘Wants to talk to her husband first.’

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Who doesn't? Roy declines Frank's phone, moves to his own. He plucks up the receiver, cleans its mouthpiece with his handkerchief, then un-holds Mrs. Fisk. The moment he does, his whole personality transforms.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Fisk? John Goodhew, regional vice-president at Allied Affiliates. Congratulations! Which prize are you hoping for? (beat) That would be my choice, too. Can I ask you one question, Irene? Do you have grandchildren? (beat) Five! How old? Well, you're a very lucky woman. Yes, I agree: they are our most precious resource. I've got a six and two- year old at home and I'll tell you: the day I installed a filtrator... Absolutely you can taste the difference. Now I understand you'd like to talk to your husband about this first, and I understand why, but the thing is, Irene -- (confidentially) -- my secretary is having a baby this afternoon and the whole office here is about to bug out and go over to the hospital. Yes, it's very exciting. But today is our deadline, so you see... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Listening, Roy nods to Frank: she's in. Frank goes to work -- calling a courier service on Roy's line (his mouth grazing the receiver, Roy notices) -- as Roy finishes up. And though his voice may be grinning, his eyes betray him: he doesn't enjoy this.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Irene, that's sweet of you to offer, and I'm sure she'd love that, but we're in Chicago. Uh- huh, cooped up in our corporate offices on State Street. I'll tell you, though, I rather be out in sunny California with you today ‘cause it's just pouring up here. Cats and dogs, exactly. Now let me confirm your address for our courier service...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy behind the wheel; Frank knots his tie. Windows up tight.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You got any thoughts on lunch? Roy nods. A long-standing joke: the non-answer answer. Frank angles his foot up on the dash, and Roy points it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy moves briskly ahead of Frank along a sidewalk, his hands thrust deep in his coat pockets, which he does whenever he's outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door answered by a MIDDLE-AGED HOUSEWIFE. Roy and Frank stand on her front porch. Roy presents identification.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Carolyn Schaffer? (as she nods) I'm Agent Kellaway, this is Agent Cole, we're from the Federal Trade Commission. Sorry to disturb you. We'd like to ask you a few questions if we could. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: Is everything alright?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: We hope so, ma'am. May we come in?

dialogues.speaker: EN
dialogues.text: Roy and Frank sit at a breakfast table, across from the Housewife testimony: and her HUSBAND. The Housewife gives her

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: He said there'd been a contest, and I'd won a prize. He said there'd be a drawing in a week, and I'd either win a trip to, um, France or Italy, I can't remember. He said if I bought one of their products, their filtration things, I wouldn't have to pay tax of the prize. She indicates a Waterford II installed on her kitchen faucet, then wilts under her husband's stare.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: Jesus, Carolyn...

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: (penitent, near tears) I was going to surprise you...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to tell you this, ma'am, but you won't be receiving any prize. And I'm sorry to tell you you've been the victim of fraud.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: (pissed, taking it out on family dog who scratches at door) Otis! Knock it off!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's not the newest swindle in the world, just new to some. They bait you with something bogus, then sell you something worthless. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How much did you give them, Mrs. Schaffer?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: Seven hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: Ah, Jesus, Carolyn... (to Frank and Roy) What's it worth?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Any hardware store they're about fifty bucks --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: But we've met people who paid twice what you did. (to Housewife) You wrote a check, ma'am? (as she nods) Did you mail it to them?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: A courier picked it up. Roy and Frank exchange grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: If they use the postal system, it's mail fraud and we can go after them. Otherwise, there's not a lot we can do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Unless...

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: Unless what?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: A lot of these sons-of-bitches -- excuse me, ma'am -- they work in syndicates. If they cashed your check out of state, it's federal and we can act. But we'd need a signed clearance from you for your bank to run a trace on the check, and then -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 8.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy takes

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: I'll give you a clearance. If it'll help get those bastards.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (to Frank) You have any more of those L-47's?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Maybe in the car. (rises to go, by chance feels inside his pocket) Wait, here we go. the form and lays it before the Husband.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Here, use my pen. As the Husband's eyes glaze over the small print, the DOG

dialogues.speaker: SCRATCHES
dialogues.text: at the door again.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: Let him out, will ya, Carolyn? The Housewife slides open a glass door for the dog, then returns to her seat -- without closing it behind her. Roy's focus fixes on it. And every voice drifts into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: All we need is the name of your bank, your account number and your signature at the bottom. Any luck, these guys were amateurs, cashed your check in Nevada.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: See, darling? I told you: you're too trusting. You gotta be more careful of people.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to say, ma'am, he's absolutely right.

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: (signing L-47) Here ya go. (off Roy's fixed, uneasy stare) You alright? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 15 Al6 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 9.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank notices now, too -- Roy is sweating and uneasy, fixated on the small wilderness outside -- and recognizes the cause of his infirmity: the open door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I close this? They don't. Frank rises and closes the glass door. Roy snaps out of it. Sound within the room returns to normal.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm fine, thanks. (he takes L-47) Thank you. Frank smiles to allay the Husband's suspicions: What the fuck was that about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Frank return to their car, Roy speedily.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're not taking your pills, are you? Roy faces him, testily, but he never pauses in his effort to get inside his car as fast as he can. Frank, admonished, takes his time getting in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's just that... you looked like you were gonna whoopsy-daisy all over those people's Oriental. A breath to compose himself and Roy STARTS the CAR.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You are taking your pills?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (at last) Yes. The car pulls out. EXT. ROY AND FRANK'S OFFICE - DAY Al6é The Caprice pulls into the parking lot. Inside, Frank splits up the day's take, fifty-fifty. Roy seems barely interested. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 10. Al6 CONTINUED: Al6

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, it's not a fortune, but it keeps me in diapers. Barely. One look at those drapes I should have known. (beat) I saw that guy again last night: Chuck. The guy I was telling you, with the --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: -- with the boat.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (sing-song) He's top-heavy. (off no response from Roy) It's real money, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: If it's real money, it's long con. I don't do long con.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You haven't done it lately. Frank is looking for a glimmer of hope. Roy gives him non

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Without me, Frank. Frank puts up his hands: never mind.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Okay. I'd just like to, you know, take a girl out somewhere nice once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (beat) You have to pay her extra for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy drops a half-dozen cans of Chicken-By-the-Sea on the conveyor. The CHECK-OUT WOMAN totals them:

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-OUT WOMAN
dialogues.text: ... four, five, six. And a pack of Winston's. For Roy, it's a standing order here.  17 18 19 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 10A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest one-story. Roy's Caprice pulls in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, shoeless, skirts the living room rug to approach a ceramic horse in the corner, next to a sofa. He slides its head up and off its body and rests it on the floor, then reaches into its hollow belly to withdraw a .38. He removes from his jacket the day's take and stuffs it inside the horse. He replaces the weapon atop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy eats dinner: tuna, straight from the can. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AT SINK
dialogues.text: He washes out the empty can, then turns to his shoes, rinsing and wiping down their soles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Predictably Spartan. Roy wears pajamas to bed. He lies down, head on his pillow, eyes toward the ceiling, wide and anxious and exhausted and sad, to smoke himself to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning ritual again. Roy stares out his window, coffee cup in hand, at the pool. And his moment of serenity has been violated for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two leaves float atop the pool surface. Roy, with a long-pole net, removes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy throws the leaves away in the trash below the sink, then rinses out his coffee mug/washes down the basin/cleans the countertop/lets the faucet run. Finds his vial of pills and taps two capsules into his palm. Sets the vial down beside the sink. Stares at the pills again -- -- then throws them back in his throat and washes them down with tap water (filtrated by a Waterford II). He reaches to turn the faucet off -- -- and accidentally knocks the uncapped vial into the sink, upending it and sending pills scattering.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Dammit! He grabs for the vial, empty -- pills are swirling down the drain -- then scrambles for the tap, slamming it off, but too late: all the capsules have been swept away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Shit! Roy frets, thinks, decides. Rolling up his sleeve, he dips his hand into the sink's disposal, patting around its base for pills. At last, he finds one. Pinches it and raises it into the light. And Roy knows: there's no way he'll ever put that thing in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's on his portable phone, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Hi, I need to talk to Mancuso. (beat) Man-cus-o. (beat) What do you mean he...? (beat) You gotta be shitting me...

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Roy frets, paces. He stops, looks down. He's been walking on the living room rug -- disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy yanks out his vacuum cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy VACUUMS the rug back-and-forth, back-and-forth, back- and-forth. He STOPS. Studies the rug. Then looks up. Suddenly everything looks dirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the sink, Roy rifles through a gallery of cleaning products -- Pine Sol, Murphy's Oil Soap, Ajax, Windex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy cleans. Dishwashing gloves on, down on his knees.  29 30 31 32 33 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy cleans behind the toilet. The PHONE RINGS in the next room. Roy shows no interest in answering it. FRANK (V.O.over message machine) Roy, pick up. It's me, pick up, Roy. Roy, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy takes his lunch break, one dishwashing glove removed, eating straight from the can again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy cleans all the windows, from the inside only -- SQUEAK, SQUEAK, SQUEAK. The PHONE RINGS again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK (V.O.on machine again) What the hell, Roy. I feel like a chick. Okay, that's it. I'm coming over.

dialogues.speaker: ROY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy sits prone on his couch. Eyes bloodshot and weary, studying the carpet. There is a KNOCK at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Roy! You in there? Roy! Roy does not respond. Frank KNOCKS some more.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Roy, goddammit! Your car's here, I know you're here! (beat) I'll call the cops, I'll do it. I'll put all my shit where they can't find it, I'll call them and they'll come down here! Roy surrenders: he gets off the couch.  14.

dialogues.speaker: AT HIS FRONT DOOR 34
dialogues.text: Roy unlocks it, opens it, latch on. Frank's nose and mouth appear in the opening. Roy shuts

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (sigh of relief) Thank Jesus. Open up, lemme in.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Take off your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Take ‘em off, or you don't come in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (looking in at him) You didn't take your pills, did you? the door, walks away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, shoes are coming off. (as he takes them off) Okay, Roy. Roy returns, unlatches and opens the door. Frank enters and the scent of ammonia slams his nostrils. Roy can't.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Mother... You get attacked by Mr. Clean? Roy, you gotta open a window.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No. Windows. (as Frank just stares at him) Looking for something?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: My partner. You seen him? He's been missing most of the week. (beat) Tell me you've left the house in three days. (CONTINUED )
Frank enters. 34

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Have you eaten anything in three days? (off Roy's nod) Besides canned tuna? (as Roy stops nodding) And women tell me my lifestyle's peculiar.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Watch -- the rug. Frank stops short of it. Looks at Roy. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You didn't take your --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I spilled them. Down the garbage disposal. By accident.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You call Mancuso?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: He moved.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You gotta be shitting me.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That's what I said.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Take a shower. I'm gonna make a call. My aunt saw this shrink after her divorce, he really --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Frank -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Roy: you need to see someone. Listen, don't think I'm doing this just for you. You got money you can retire, I got car payments, you know. I don't need a partner who's -- Frank pantomimes a mad-act spasm. Roy relents. As he heads for the bathroom, Frank picks up the phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Wipe that thing down when you're done with it, okay? A beat. Frank looks to be at the end of his rope.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Go take that shower, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beside a door, a plaque reads: "DR. HARRIS KLEIN, M.D." Roy watches from a darkened breezeway, smoking, hands in coat pockets. He stamps out his cigarette and approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, at the far end of a small couch, stares at a pair of Florsheims crossed atop an ottoman. They belong to DR. KLEIN, who scans Roy's form.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: You mind if I put them up? It helps my back.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: (re: his form) You're something of a clean slate, Roy. This says you were on medication but you don't know what kind. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: They were green capsules. I think it said P.D.F. on them. Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: You were getting them illegally? (as Roy balks) We're starting fresh today, Roy. What happened in the past I don't care about.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That's a funny thing for a shrink to say. Klein smiles; Roy doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Yes. I was getting them illegally.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: So I wouldn't have to talk to someone like you. Do you know what they were?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Yes. And at the dosage you say you were taking, I'd say you were lucky to be sitting up straight!--

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Can you get me more of them?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Let's talk a little first. It says here you're --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: -- I'm sorry, Doc, but my partner, my buddy Frank --

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: -- Beth Mercer's nephew -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: -- he said I could come here and you'd get me the pills I need. If you can't do that, this session's over before it's started.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: You certainly get to the point.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: And you skirt it. Can you get me the pills or not?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Then let's get that prescription pad out.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Roy, usually I don't prescribe medicine unless I've had a little chat with the patient first. If you're inclined against that, then!-- as you say -- this session will be quite brief. Roy stares the doctor down. Klein never blinks.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: It says here you're an antiques dealer. How long you been in that line? Nothing from Roy. The face-off continues.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Would you like to tell me what's been bothering you? And continues. Then, abruptly, Roy quits.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I get tired a lot, but I can't sleep. Certain things distract me, make me feel sick to my stomach.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: What kinds of things? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: When people leave doors open, or windows. I don't like being outdoors. They call that agoraphobia, right?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Incorrectly, but yes. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Dirt. Especially around moldings. Klein makes a note. A beat. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Have these distractions affected your work of late? (off Roy's nod) And your personal relationships?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What personal relationships?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: When was the last time you were in one? A relationship?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: With a woman? A long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Five years? Ten years?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: What was her name?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Heather.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Were you married? (off Roy's nod) Kids? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Maybe. That's a new one.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: She was pregnant when she left me. Maybe I got a kid, maybe I don't.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: You haven't seen her since?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: You haven't spoken?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: She left with a black eye, which I gave her, and a bun in the oven, which might have come from anyone. So, no, I haven't. For all I know she got hit by a bus. For all I know she got rid of the baby, ‘cause she'd been down that path before. (a breath to cool his temper) Doc: I spent last Tuesday on my living room sofa. Watching my carpet. Watching fibers on my carpet. And the whole time I was watching my carpet I was worrying that I might vomit, and the whole time I was worrying I might vomit, I was thinking: I’m a grown man, I should know what's going on in my head. And the more I thought about it the more I realized I should just blow my brains out and end it all, but the more I wanted to blow my brains out, the more I thought about what that would do to my goddamn carpet. (beat) And that was a good day, Doc. So gimme some pills and let me get on with my life.  38 39

dialogues.speaker: B39
dialogues.text: 40 41 42 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 10/7/02 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy pushes a blue capsule out of a foil-bottom packet, downs it with coffee. He stops to think.

dialogues.speaker: AT TABLE
dialogues.text: He opens the phone book, flips pages to "F." His finger scans names, comes up empty. He closes the book in surrender.

dialogues.speaker: ON PHONE
dialogues.text: He hasn't quit yet, poised with pen and pad.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: -- Fenton. F-e-n-t-o-n. Heather. (waits, then) What about in Orange County?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy sits on the edge of the bed, staring at Heather's number. He picks up his phone, starts to dial, then hangs up. He's scared shitless. He closes his eyes, breathless, sucks down part of a Winston. Then picks up the phone again, dials. ONE RING, TWO RINGS...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello -- Roy hangs up. Buries his hands under his armpits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42  MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 10/7/02 22/23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klein studies Roy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I was young, she was very young. We met in a bar. Discovered we both had similar interests. Basically, drinking and -- He waves his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Sexual intercourse.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: If you gotta be dirty about it. Then we got hitched. I don't think either of us put a whole lot of thought into it.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: And she got pregnant. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 24.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy nods. 43

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That was later. After things got bad. We fought a lot.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What have you got? I wasn't sober a lot then --

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Are you now?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (nods ) -- so some nights she just didn't come home. She was pregnant two months before she told me. Which is why I...

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Hit her?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Do you think about her much? What could have been, what might have been. Roy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: And the baby?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: If there's a baby.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Do you think about that?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Sometimes. Rarely. If I seea school bus or -- I wonder: Is one of those kids Roy Jr.?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: He -- if he's a he -- would be how old now?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Fourteen. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 25.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Fourteen. Ready to be a man.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: If he's a he. If he is at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy waits. Dr. Klein appears from his stockroom/closet and hands Roy a handful of unlabeled sampler packs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Congratulations. You bought yourself a month's worth.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Doc, do you know of a way of...? Just to find out...

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: There's nothing wrong, Roy, with a man telephoning his ex-wife.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I tried that last night. (withdraws the number from his shirt pocket) Couldn't say a word. Klein looks surprised. Roy pushes the number on him.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Could you? Call her?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: I don't know, Roy. I, uh...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Just to find out. Klein hesitates: This is unorthodox. But that's what Roy wants. At last, Klein relents; he takes Heather's number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, rock-like, stares out at the pool. The PHONE RINGS. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: (on the answering machine) Roy? This is Dr. Klein...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (picking up) Doc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's on the portable. Roy can't DR. KLEIN (V.O.on phone) I just got off the phone with Heather. We had a nice conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Does she want to talk to me? DR. KLEIN (V.O.on phone) No. She doesn't. I'm sorry. She didn't understand it might help with your therapy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You told her I was in therapy. DR. KLEIN (V.O.on phone) I told her I was a psychiatrist. I can't lie, Roy. Angela wants to talk to you, though.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Who? DR. KLEIN (V.O.on phone) Angela. Your daughter. She knows you're her father, and she says she really wants to meet you. move or speak for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Doc, can you hold the line a moment? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy cups the phone. Carries it inside the bathroom. Turns on the light and shuts the door behind him. Through the door: The unmistakable convulsions of a man puking up everything he has. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ROY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING UNDER a highway sign: SAN PEDRO. Then DOWN TO: Roy's Caprice, Roy at the wheel, white knuckles at two and ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for one young mother and her infant, empty. Stopped across the street, Roy checks his watch -- he's early. He burrows out a cigarette, lights it, and unrolls his window an eighth of an inch.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Roy is chain-lighting his next cigarette, then pushing the old butt through the window crack, when in his side mirror: A YOUNG GIRL floats INTO VIEW atop a skateboard. Pretty but not fully formed, slender but not fragile. She rides past his Caprice, then dismounts and walks into the park. Roy doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: The Young Girl sits waiting, rolling her skateboard back- and-forth. Roy remains in his car, watching, amazed, bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: The Girl stands, looks this way and that, then gives up. She mounts her board and starts away, and as she passes Roy's car, he can see: there's disappointment in her eyes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Shit. Roy throws open his car door.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Hey -- hey!! The Girl stops. Roy stumbles out of his Caprice, clothes disheveled, cigarette dangling from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You Angela?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA, (YOUNG GIRL)
dialogues.text: You Roy? He nods. Father and daughter meet.

dialogues.speaker: ON PARK SWINGS 52
dialogues.text: Angela rocks gently. Roy stands nearby, on pavement, not sand, hands deep in his pockets. He doesn't know what to say, except:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: So: You're fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Yep. She swings a little more.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: When'd you get out?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Of prison. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I've never been in prison.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Oh. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Your mom tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: First she told me you were dead. Then she said you might as well be.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm not dead. I'm in antiques.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: That's what the doctor said. On the phone. When he said that, Mom started to laugh. Roy glances about, anxious.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You -- you hungry? (as she shrugs) Do you mind eating? It's just -- I'd feel better somewhere indoors. I get uncomfortable sometimes being outside. She gives him a curious look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela is served an enormous meal (turkey, mashed and gravy, chocolate shake), and Roy takes note from across the table.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I thought you weren't hungry.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You're gonna get wet, might as well go swimming.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What's that thing with girls -- where they don't eat?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (mouth full) Anorexia. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: At least we know you don't have that.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I could have bulimia. That's when you go in the bathroom after and vomit. She continues to eat. Roy studies her face.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You're staring.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: That's okay. I used to do it, too. Look at your picture and see if I got your nose or your eyes. Mom used to say I got lucky and only got your elbows.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How is your mom?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Fine. Roy waits: Is there more information forthcoming? Angela eats, deliberately: No, there isn't.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: So you're in school, right?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Not now. It's summer.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Right. Well, school's real important. If I had anything to do over again, I'd work harder in school.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You drop out? Roy hesitates, then nods.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: That why you ended up a criminal? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She takes a long, noisy slurp from her shake, sucking up the dregs with her straw as she studies Roy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You finished?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: It's okay, you know. Whatever you do. Everybody's done something bad in their life --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: -- I'm in antiques --

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: -- if you make it a career, it's just a lot of something strung together --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Cut the shit, huh? I'm not a criminal. (beat) Sorry. I shouldn't've --

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (mock shock) What -- what was that word? ‘Shi...t'? (unfazed) When's the last time you saw each other, you and Mom?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Before you were born.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You still love her? He doesn't know how to answer.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: ‘Cause she still hates you, you know.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I pretty much figured that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy drives. Angela, snooping, opens the glove compartment, eyes a pack of cigarettes along with Roy's pink slip, proof of insurance, fake FTC identification. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (shooing her away) Hey, hey... Looking up the street:

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Stop, stop, stop. That's her car in the driveway. You better drop me here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy pulls over. Time to say good-bye. He doesn't know how.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Got a pen? He does. She takes it, then his hand, and writes a telephone number on his palm.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: This is my private line. Mom got it for me for my birthday. ‘Cause my friend Carrie kept on calling after midnight. Maybe we could go bowling some time. Roy is caught off-guard by the suggestion. Angela leaps out, then leans back in.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you, Dad. She closes the door. Roy watches her skate away, then glances at the number written on his palm. It absolutely bewilders him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What's more important than family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's at his desk. Copying the number fading from his palm. He can't help but smile. Meanwhile, Frank works the phones, fighting the monotony of cold calling. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 57 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 33.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Then what could be more important than purifying the water your family drinks? The Waterford II offers you the cleanest filtration system available today. (notices Roy's smile) Mr. Schlickling, can you hold just one moment? Thank you. (muting the phone, to Roy) What?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're smiling. You switch shampoos or something? (beat) Pills working? (as Roy nods) Glad one of us is happy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (moment's thought, then) How much money you think we could take that guy for? Chuck, with the boat. (off Frank's astonishment) Figure I owe you one. Frank can't believe it. He stares at Roy. Then back on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Mr. Schlickling? Hi, I'm sorry: you waited too long, no prize for you. And he hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHUCK FRECHETTE -- swarthy, forty-something, new-money suit -- brow-beats the illegal alien who's towel-drying his Mercedes (complete with bumper sticker "I'd Rather Be Sailing"). Across the street, Roy and Frank scout him.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (tell me again) What's his last name? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Frechette. Chuck Frechette.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How do you spell it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: F-R... Hell if I know, he's from Downey.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Where'd you find him?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Cheetah's. Watched him drop two G's there a month ago.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Cheetah's?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's a gentlemen's --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I know what it is. What's he do?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Import/export.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: He's not connected, is he?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He and the mob are like this -- Frank holds two fingers far apart. Meanwhile, Frechette's MERCEDES is as dry as it's gonna get. He gets in and PEELS AWAY, leaving his dryer's upturned palm empty.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Sonovabitch didn't even tip.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I figure on short notice he could scratch up at least thirty grand.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (beat) More. Music to Frank's ears. Roy KEYS the IGNITION.  58 59 60 61 62 63 64 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy enters. As we hear him continue --

dialogues.speaker: ROY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We'll pull the Jamaican switch on him. He knows you, so you're rope, I'm inside. Think he knows anything about international finance? -- he moves briskly through --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- then into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where he approaches a CLERK.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'd like to access my safe deposit box. J-215.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: (offering a form) Signature and pass code, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bank Clerk removes a large safety deposit box, sets it on a viewing table, then leaves Roy alone with it. Roy opens it, then withdraws from his jacket two envelopes -- one white, one manila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy faces his professional costume closet: several suits, high to low end, plus a gallery of pristine shoes, a number of pairs of eyeglasses. Roy tries on a pair, checks himself in the mirror.  65 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy on the phone again.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Where? (checking his watch) Where else. One hour. He hangs up. A KNOCK at the door. Roy looks alarmed. He just got off the phone with Frank -- who else could that be?

dialogues.speaker: AT FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Opening on Angela, backpack and skateboard at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Remember me? Roy nods, bemused.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You just in the neighborhood?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Took the bus. Think I could come in a sec? Panic flickers across Roy's face. No one but Frank has crossed this threshold in many years. He opens the door wider and she steps inside. She peers about.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: It's nice. Your place. I bet you're wondering how I got your address. He wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Off your car insurance, in your glove compartment. Roy feels suddenly uncomfortable in his own home. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: So what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Mom and I had sort of a fight. It happens once in a while. I usually take off for a day or two to let her calm down.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Take off?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Normally I go to Carrie's. Only her family's on vacation. And I thought, since we seemed to hit it off so good last time -- (hoping Roy will complete the thought; he doesn't) -- I could sleep on the couch?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (cardiac arrest) You wanna stay here?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I could pay you back by cleaning up or something -- (as she gazes around spotless room; then re: his glasses) You wear those to read? They make you look kinda old.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: These're just for -- (remembering) I gotta go. I got a business meeting.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: This late?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Antiques wait for no man. (half to himself, half to her) Is it okay if I leave you here?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Sure. I can watch TV. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 66 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 38.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy searches around the room, as if a television will magically appear.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You don't have a TV? You seriously don't have a TV? He smiles, sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: There's a couch. If you want to sit. Or there if you prefer. Or the couch. She moves to the couch, amused by his nervousness; of course, she treads right across the carpet. Roy averts his eyes, starts for the door...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You want me to pick up anything on the way back? Ice cream?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: New York Super Fudge Chunk.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: That's my favorite flavor. New York Super Fudge Chunk.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: New York...?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Super Fudge Chunk.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Chocolate. Don't open the door for anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quietly as he can, Roy locks the front door. Hesitates for a moment. Can he do this -- leave a fourteen-year- old girl alone in his house? He must.  67 68 69 70 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy pulls his Caprice into a distant view of the club. Frank taps on the passenger side window and Roy unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (re: Roy's glasses) Hey, I like those. They make you look --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Old?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then) Older.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How long's he been inside?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You got your lines down?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You got my money? Roy withdraws the standard white envelope from his jacket and flings it at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As glamorous an establishment as you might imagine. Roy enters, pays the cover charge at the door and spots -- by way of a mirror -- Chuck Frechette drinking alone at the bar. He finds himself a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Roy's away, Angela snoops. Here she opens drawers: just clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here she opens cupboards: just cans of Chicken-of-the- Sea.  71 72 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here she stands on a chair and pries atop bookshelves: nothing here, not even dust. But from this perch, the ceramic horse in the corner draws her attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Roy sips a club soda:

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Good evening. His eyes stray up to hers (who knows the last time he faced a bare midriff) --

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Care for a dance? -- then flash to the door as Frank enters. Frank spots Roy and heads his way. Roy glances back at the bar: Frechette, eyes on the girls, didn't notice Frank enter.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Not just now. The Stripper departs, passing Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thanks, honey. Come back later for me, though, okay? Frank stands over Roy and extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Arden. Hope I didn't keep you.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (rising to shake) Good to see you, Bob. (voice dropping) At the bar. He missed you come in. Frank nods, then whistles to a passing waitress, loudly:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hey, can I get a Bud?! Everyone turns their heads at that, including Frechette, who recognizes Frank. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (back to Roy) That do the trick?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Let's sit. They do. Frechette starts off his barstool toward them. Roy monitors his approach.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We in business?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: On my next drink. Another stripper passes, and Roy's distracted an instant.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I told you you'd like it here. Roy picks up his drink, cueing Frank to reach into his windbreaker, remove the white envelope, and drop it on the table --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don't spend it all on one girl, huh? -- so that it lands just as Frechette arrives, tie tugged loose, whiskey in hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Hey, Bob...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (he turns) Hey, Chuck, I didn't know you were here. Frank stands to shake hands, but Frechette's eyes drop to the white envelope on the table: a slim stack of $100's peeks out from within. Roy notes Frechette's glance and quickly palms the envelope into his lap.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) Ah, Chuck Frechette, this is my friend, Arden -- Roy shoots Frank a look: no names. Frank shuts up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Hiya. Roy nods hello, none-too-pleased, then resumes his stare at Frank: get him out of here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Frechette, confidentially) Say, Chuck, we got a little business to settle up here. You mind if -- Frechette gets the idea fast: something not-quite-legal is going down here, and he's not welcome.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Sure, Bob. I'1l be over at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Great. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: (to Roy) Nice meeting you. Frechette retreats, curiosity piqued. Frank sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fish in a barrel. Roy waits until Frechette has returned to his barstool and is clandestinely watching and then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- he removes the manila envelope from his coat and hands it to Frank/"Bob": a trade.

dialogues.speaker: BACK WITH ROY AND FRANK
dialogues.text: As Frank glances inside Roy's manila envelope (filled with British pounds), Roy glances at Frechette, whose attention jerks back to the girls.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: He's piqued. You good to go? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 73 74 75 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 43.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Does the Pope shit in the woods?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Just say yes, okay? (rising) So long, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: See you in the morning, Arden. Roy leaves Frank, ignoring Frechette on his way out the door. As soon as he's gone, Frechette starts toward Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy picks his way through various cartons of ice cream. Squints through his fogged glasses, then remembers he does not need them.

dialogues.speaker: AT SAME CHECK-OUT
dialogues.text: A carton of New York Super Fudge Chunk makes its way down the conveyor to join a few more cans of tuna. The Check- Out Woman adds a pack of Winstons to the bunch.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-OUT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Big night planned?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, it's not for me.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-OUT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Right. You have kids overnight? Roy laughs at the absurdity of this. The Check-Out Woman doesn't understand, of course, but she laughs with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy enters, locks the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Angela? She sleeps atop the couch, arms and legs splayed every which way. Roy approaches, sets down the ice cream, and!--!for the first time in his career as parent -- finds a blanket to drape over her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 44.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (groggily) Roy?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: How was your meeting?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Good. I sold a nice piece. Angela smiles, half-asleep. He starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Why'd Mom leave you?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You'd have to ask her.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I did. She didn't want to talk about it. Called you names. That's why we got into a fight. Roy smiles. Touched she stuck up for him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: She said you were a bad guy. You don't seem like a bad guy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That's what makes me good at it. He rises, heads to his room, and just before he turns off the living room light, Angela rolls over under her blanket, eyes closed, murmuring:

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I don't think you're a bad guy. Roy smiles, shuts the light off. Immediately: KNOCK- KNOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is knocking. Roy opens the door, squints at the light, careful not to let Frank peer in. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 77 78 79 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 45.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I wish you could have been there. Oh, I reeled him in --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Do we have to do this now?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I got your money.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Shh-shh-shh. Conscious of Angela asleep inside, Roy slides out the door and closes it behind him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What's going on? (shocked) You don't have someone in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Frank huddle on the sidewalk, Roy out of doors and anxious. Frank returns the manila envelope to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The second you left the place, he was off his barstool. He's in. Oh, man, is he in. He wants to meet tonight. Roy glances back at his house. A window shade shifts slightly: is Angela spying?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Push it to tomorrow. Lunch. Let his greed meet his imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy returns to find his couch empty and the shower water running in the bathroom. He seizes the opportunity to sneak both envelopes of cash into the ceramic horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela, her hair still wet, digs a spoon into the pint of New York Super Fudge Chunk. Roy, meanwhile, sneaks his morning medication down his throat. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 46.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You sure I can't give you a ride home?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: That's okay. Mom can pick me up. Roy reacts: the prospect of confronting Heather rattles him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Who was that guy who came by earlier?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Who? Oh. A business associate.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: How come you didn't want him to see me?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I didn't not want him to see you. (re: ice cream) Shouldn't you... eat eggs or something?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: All you've got here is tuna. Lots and lots of tuna. And one TV dinner. TV dinners are cool. You should get the TV to go with ‘em. Roy stiffens, pissed: someone went snooping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela's on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Hi... No... No... Guess... (beat) What if I am? So? He's my father... (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ANGELA (CONT'Dbeat) I don't care. I don't care. I will if I want. Across the room, Roy grows more distressed as Angela grows more petulant. Now she quiets down.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I know. I know. Okay, I promise. Yes, I promise! ‘Bye. She hangs up abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: She mad?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: At me. Not you. Roy looks relieved.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: She said she was gonna call the police -- So much for relief.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: -- but now she just wants me home in time for summer school.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: When's that?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Monday.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Today's Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: That's okay, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy is doubled over on the couch, his arms sagging down across his legs, head buried between his knees. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: And one more time, deeply... (as Roy breathes in) Hold it -- one, two, three, four!-- and out.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You've got stains.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: In your carpet.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: You can sit up. (as Roy does) Is that what you were thinking about? Stains in my carpet?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: And that I have a fourteen-year- old girl I barely know living in my house.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: It's just for the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: But I've got a -- there's a big piece coming on the market I'm brokering and -- it's just not a good time.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: When is it ever a good time for anything? I realize this is sudden, Roy, and you may feel unprepared, but trust me, they’re not so difficult, kids. Most of all you have to focus on the basics: make sure they eat their vegetables, don 't stay up too late, and don't watch too much TV. Otherwise just try to be as honest and open with them as possible. Roy eyes a picture of two little boys atop Klein's desk.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: As honest and open as possible. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: She's your daughter, Roy. Unless there's another ex-wife you haven't told me about, she's the only one you got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy pulls home, pushing a pill from its packet, swallowing it dry, his second dose of the day. He gets out to find --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela lies by the pool on a beach towel in a bikini and dark glasses, reading a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: How'd the meeting go? Did it go okay? Confronted by his daughter's breasts, hips and calves, Roy walks straight into the house.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What's the matter? You freaking out about something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squash, broccoli, artichokes, cauliflower, etc. Standing behind a cart, Roy stares at them blankly. In the frozen food aisle, Roy reads directions on a package of frozen spinach. Angela appears behind him, carrying chips, cookies, and a six-pack of beer.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Who's that for?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Don't you drink?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Do you?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Come on. I'm fourteen. Roy isn't sure which way to take that.  85 86 87 88 89 90 50.

dialogues.speaker: IN LINE FOR ROY'S USUAL CHECK-OUT WOMAN 85
dialogues.text: Roy and Angela wait behind two other shoppers.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: The line for that one's shorter.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: This one's better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy cooks. His first attempt in years. He serves. Limp spinach and sauceless spaghetti. Seated at his breakfast table, neither he nor Angela look too ecstatic about digging in. He surrenders. A pizza delivery box takes center stage on the breakfast table; the spinach and pasta lie untouched in the kitchen sink. Angela bites into a slice as Roy forks a fresh can of tuna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning ritual begins again. Roy, dressed, leaves his bedroom, closes its door behind him, proceeds to the bathroom door, opens it --

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just a minute. Roy closes it fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy cleans his coffee mug/wipes down the sink/waits. He's pissed his morning routine has been interrupted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela exits, in a towel, allowing Roy to enter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like a circus act of seals has come and gone. Water everywhere, used towels, underpants hanging from a faucet. Roy uses a piece of toilet paper to remove them.  91 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, bespectacled again, sits at a table with Frank and Frechette, who are halfway through lunch. Roy sticks with just coffee.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Bob tells me you're a yachtsman.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Hardly. Just a forty-two footer I take out on weekends. You sail?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I get seasick in the tub.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Arden, you sure you don't want something?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Thanks. I gotta fly in two hours. (To Frechette) The cast iron stomach again.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Where you off to?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Phoenix. A client's setting up a funding account to bridge the pound and the euro, I've got to hold his hand. (to passing waitress) Hon: could you heat this up a little, please?

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: That bad, huh?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: For some folks, money is a foreign film without subtitles. Anyway, to the business at hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: To the business at hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I have one rule, Chuck: simple is safe. I'm going to tell you as little as possible about me and what I do, but as much as I need to make you comfortable with what we're doing. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 51a. CONTINUED: (Al) 91

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: What are we doing? Roy removes a manila envelope from his jacket, just as he did at Cheetah's, but reaches it under the table to Frechette. Frechette peeks inside: thin stacks of hundred pound notes.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: How much is it? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frechette 52. 91

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Five thousand pounds sterling. One of the perks of working in the exchange program at a bank.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Whose is it?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No one's in particular. Justa little money unaccounted for, floating on top the books like a layer of cream.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And he just scoops it off.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: It's a little more complicated than that but again: simple is safe.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Why not keep the money yourself?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: As a bank employee any attempt I make to change currency is recorded and questioned. Bob has a record. You, on the other hand, no one bats an eye. (beat) Now I hope you have something for me. nods, removes an envelope from his jacket and reaches it under the table.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Five grand American. Roy checks, pockets Frechette's money.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Congratulations. At today's exchange rate, you just made two thousand --

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: -- five hundred sixty-seven dollars. I looked it up on the Internet. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The frickin' Internet. I still can't figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Neither can I. But my daughter's a wiz at the thing. Roy goes off-book.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You have a daughter?

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Two. Fifteen and twelve.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I have a fourteen-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: It's a riot, huh? Training bras hanging from your shower rod...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: «+. and everything smells like gum. (suddenly has a thousand questions to ask Frechette) How do you get ‘em out of the house? Mine just sits at home all day.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Summer's the worst. Frank reacts: what the hell is Roy talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the valet station:

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Lemme ask you something, Arden: how much could you do this for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hypothetically.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: As a rule: we never go north of ten -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy quiets Frank, eyes Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How much could you get your hands on? Frechette smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Stiffing his valet, Frechette drives his Mercedes away. Frank and Roy watch him go. Frank sighs in relief.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: For a second I thought we were out two grand.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You gotta spend money to make money.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: But you gotta make it to spend it. (beat) ‘Everything smells like gum?' What was that about? Roy hesitates, then:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: It's easier if I show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy unlocks the front door and enters, with Frank behind him. From within:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Angela! Angela, I'm back! (beat) Angela? Frank's here! (farther inside) Angela?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank reads a fashion magazine from Angela's bag. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: She's not here. She must have gone back to her mom's.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Her bag's still here. Where does she usually go?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't know anything about her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This is no good for you, Roy. Or us.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: It's got nothing to do with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy can be seen through the blinds, watching the pool, turning its light on and off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ashtray overflows on the coffee table. Roy waits on the couch and lights a fresh one. He checks his watch: it's late. A dull THUNK comes from the back of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Roy opens the door: Angela is brushing off her jeans. The window is open.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I've been waiting over an hour. Where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I went to the arcade. It's only like a half-mile away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 56.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He moves to the window, shuts it.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: It's stuffy in here. This whole house smells like Lysol.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Where the hell were you? I want to know right now or I'm calling your mother.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I told you, the arcade --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Why'd you sneak back in?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: That's how I left. I don't have keys to lock the door.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You didn't see my car? Roy squats to pluck up specks of dirt Angela tracked in.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Jeez, you're worse than Mom.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Listen, Angela: I'm glad we met, but I've got a business, a partner, and I've got things a certain way, and that's it. Sol think it would be better, for you most of all, if tomorrow morning I took you back home. Roy brushes the dirt into a trash can.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What did I do wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You didn't do anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I just went out. I didn't drink, I didn't get high, and I didn't take any money out of your stupid horse. (as Roy goes white) So, what, you never heard of a bank?  98 99 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy slides the head off his ceramic horse, checks his -38, then starts pulling out wads of cash. As he counts it, FOOTSTEPS march down the hall, punctuated by the front DOOR SLAMMING. Roy looks up. Should he go after her? He turns back to his money: it looks all there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela stalks away from Roy's house, book bag and skateboard in hand. Roy emerges far behind her and runs to catch her. She, meanwhile, mounts her board.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Angela! I wasn't kicking you out.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I don't want to stay where I'm not wanted.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: It's not that I don't want you.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Fooled me.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Will you stop? He catches her.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Let me go. (as he does) You just don't want me going home to Mom saying she was right all along. You're like one of her boyfriends: I'm just something you have to deal with in order to screw her.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Angela...

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (much too loudly) Even they tell me what they do for a living. Oh, yeah, antique dealers always keep large stacks of cash in their homes. Right next to their guns... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 58.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy shushes her, but he knows: she's got him.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. I'm sorry. I'm just... not good at being a father, alright? You know? I barely get by as me. Roy takes his hand out of his coat pocket to wipe a tear off her cheek. She recoils.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Will you come back home with me? We can get pizza again. She won't budge.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You can stay the whole weekend if you want. She won't budge. Roy doesn't know what else to offer but:

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Why do you have a gun?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: In case.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: In case what? Roy is stuck. He sighs, resigned.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: It's a little hard to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela and Roy face off over another pizza.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Nope. No bullshit. And watch your language at the table.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You're a con man? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 58A.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Con artist. Flim-flam man, matchstick man, take your pick.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: And that guy Frank?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: My partner. My protege. (CONTINUED )
100 She considers it. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I told you: watch your goddamn language.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Teach me something.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Teach me something. A con.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You're funny.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Teach me something.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I am not going to teach you anything.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Because. You're a beautiful, bright, innocent girl, and I'm not going to screw that up like everything else.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Really, you think that?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: That I'm beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (deadpan) No. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Then why won't you?! (mockingly) Because crime doesn't pay?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No. It does pay. Just not very well.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You seem to be doing okay by it. Roy stops.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm not. Believe me. It's not fun doing what I do. A lot of the time it's stealing from people who don't deserve it. Old people. Fat people. A lot of the time I feel sick about it.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (calling his bluff) Then why do you keep doing it? Roy has no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Roy brushes his teeth, Angela sits atop the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I'm not as innocent as you think. I've done stuff with boys. I've done stuff, if I told you, you'd probably throw up right here.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Then don't tell me.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Teach me something!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No! final!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: At the Christmas dance last year, I went with this boy, Josh Ward, he's cute and I really really liked him... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm not listening.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: After the dance, at Carrie's, we went upstairs, and he pushed me up against the bed...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm not listening.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: And he took his hand...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: One thing! I'11 show you one thing! She nearly jumps for joy. Kisses him on the cheek, getting toothpaste on her face, then skips down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: And then you're never gonna do it again. You're gonna forget it. Agreed? But she's already frolicking into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cruising down the freeway. Angela brings a notebook out of her backpack full of laundry.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Where we going?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Rule number one. Never work near where you live.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (writing) ‘Don't... shit... where... you...’

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (grabs, throws notebook) Rule number two. Don't write anything down.  103 104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy exits the Caprice, enters the 7-Eleven. Angela follows.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Stay in the car. (as she still follows) Stay in the car. She still follows. Roy gives up.
103 104 Roy marks a lottery ticket as Angela watches: four of the five numbers -- 6, 18, 22, 49, 60 -- which (a prominent sign displays) won the day before. To the

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I want to play this for the drawing on the twenty-second.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: You know the odds of the lottery hitting the same numbers in the same month, the same numbers ever?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That's why I changed one.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: You're wasting your dollar.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You his financial advisor?

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: No. You're a cashier at a 7-Eleven. Take his dollar and give hima ticket for the twenty-second. The Cashier hops to it. Roy considers Angela, amused.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You sure you're ready for this?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I was born ready.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm glad I missed that day.  105 106 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy crumples up his lottery ticket, rolls it in his hand, scratches hard at it with his fingernail. Angela, sipping on a Big Gulp, takes it from him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I've got longer nails. Roy watches her scratch away with all her might.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Just the... right. (beat) Okay. Most important thing you have to understand about this game is: ninety percent of it is variable. No matter how good your plan is, you almost always get thrown a curveball. So you have to be flexible, prepared to roll with anything. The one thing you can control, though, is who your mark is. That's your ten percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela enters, backpack on her arm. She cases the joint. A single man, black, sits reading Tolstoy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Never play someone who's not buying what you're selling. What you're selling is you. An elderly couple separates whites and colors.

dialogues.speaker: ROY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The older the better, but beware of couples. You don't want anyone whispering in your mark's ear but you. A boy in his teens returns her interest.

dialogues.speaker: ROY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And, for God's sake, make sure the person you're conning isn't conning you. Angela gives him a get-lost look, then turns to a middle- aged HOUSEWIFE loading three machines. Angela approaches. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (re: washer beside her) That taken?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Sure you don't need it? You've got a lot.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: This is nothing. You oughta catch me during Little League season. Three boys.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Any of ‘em cute? The Housewife smiles, and Angela smiles back: she has her mark. She sets her bag down, stealthily planting the lottery ticket beneath it.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Angela and the Housewife transfer their laundry to dryers. Her dryer

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
