dialogues.text: Simon's about your age, but you'd never guess; he's so hyper. You know, girls really do mature much faster than boys.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: That's what I keep telling my brothers.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: They don't go to Fremont, do they?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Central. full, Angela picks up her backpack to go.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get a Coke across the street. Do you want anything? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: No thanks, honey. Angela starts off, and the Housewife notices the lottery ticket left behind.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: Honey, you dropped something. She holds it for her to see.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: It's not mine.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Gotta be eighteen to play.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: Huh. Looks like someone put it through the wash by accident. It's for yesterday's drawing. That says the second, don't you think? Angela inspects it, too: thanks to her and Roy's handiwork, the date looks like the second, not the twenty-second.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Probably a loser. The Housewife nods, and Angela continues on her way. But on second thought:

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: We should at least see if it hit.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS LAUNDRY
dialogues.text: A man reads a newspaper. The Housewife approaches with Angela.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir? Could we borrow your paper a sec? We're looking for lottery results. The newspaper drops. The man is Roy. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Sure. I think it's Metro... Roy hands her the section. The Housewife opens it, passes Angela the ticket. Roy rises to feed a dryer (whose clothes are inside is anybody's guess).

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: Ready? Six, eighteen, thirty, forty-nine, sixty.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Wait, wait. Six, eighteen, what?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: Thirty, forty-nine, sixty.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Thirty? You're sure? (as Housewife nods) Missed by one.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Look!

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: You mean we missed by one number -- ? She looks -- it's true! They laugh, a little breathless, a little crestfallen. Then, it's back to the wash.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: Story of my life.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Mine, too.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (as he returns) Any luck?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Four out of five, can you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Four out of five pays, you know. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Angela and the Housewife share a look, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: It does?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Call the number on the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Housewife's on a pay phone. Angela hovers nearby.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Uh-huh, uh-huh. Thank you very much. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What'd they say?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: (face erupting) We won six hundred dollars!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Holy -- She cups her mouth: oops.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: -- shit! Six hundred dollars!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Holy shit! Roy watches from inside as they laugh and hug.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: The woman on the phone said we just have to take it in for verification. And then they'll mail me a check. (quickly) I'll give you half, sweetie, don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You don't have to... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: No, no, we're fifty-fifty in this. In fact, we should call your mom and we can all go down there together. Angela pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: She works. Pretty late.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: How ‘bout your dad?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (ashamed ) He -- he doesn't live with us anymore. You know, it's okay. I'm supposed to be home anyway.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: No, no, no. We're in this fifty- fifty. The Housewife stops to think -- what to do? Then she turns to see a bank ATM across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Housewife uses the ATM; Angela's feet are barely IN FRAME behind her. Angela very consciously keeps OUT OF the CAMERA'S RANGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy watches from inside his Caprice.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Good girl, watch the cameras.

dialogues.speaker: AT ATM 111
dialogues.text: The Housewife hands Angela three crisp $100s.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: That’s three hundred. Don't spend it all at the coin-op. And hide it when you get home. Don't let those brothers of yours anywhere near it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 69.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (touched) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEWIFE
dialogues.text: Thank you, sweetie. They hug again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela exits with her backpack full of laundry, waves goodbye once more to the Housewife, then rounds a corner to find Roy waiting for her, out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Did I do good?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You did very good. She leaps in the air.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Mom was wrong: I didn't just get your elbows.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: One last thing...

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Go give her her money back.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I told you I'd teach you acon, I didn't say I'd let you get away with it.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: C'mon! You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Now. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 70.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (can't believe it) This is so... Roy points: go. Petulantly, Angela stalks back inside. Roy watches through a glass wall as she hands the money back to the Housewife, utterly befuddled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving Angela home.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I have one question for you. And I want you to think before answering. (as she nods okay) Did you feel better when you took her money, or when you gave it back? (before she answers) Think first. Angela thinks.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I thought we were partners.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm not your partner. I'm your father. Angela puts her feet up on the dash. Roy doesn't mind.

dialogues.speaker: ROY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's strange. Two weeks ago this was ancient history. Now suddenly I have a daughter.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: And I'm not... scared shitless. That's good, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: It's however you feel about it, Roy. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 71.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DR. KLEIN (CONT'Dbeat) Yes. It's wonderful. Don't take this too literally, but you've been closing doors for a long time. It's good to see you start opening some again. Roy looks a little worried.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I -- I took Angela along over the weekend, selling a piece. Sometimes in my business you have to create a value in something which really isn't there. What some people call sales, other people call...

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Lying.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I didn't know how Angela would go for that. But she took right to it. She even helped out, this fourteen-year-old girl, working these people with me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Do you regret it? Exposing her to that? Her seeing that side of you?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (moment of truth) I really liked it. It was the best time we've had together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy opens his refrigerator door. Inside are grease- stained pizza cartons and Chinese food cartons. He closes it, considers the room around him. It's cluttered with fashion magazines, empty soda cans, a real mess. And it's very quiet, for the first time in a while. And lonely.  116 117 118 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cans of tuna again. But also some fresh vegetables, frozen pizzas, and TV dinners.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-OUT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Where's that cute little girl of yours?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: She went home to her mom's. Summer school.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-OUT WOMAN
dialogues.text: She's a cute one. Must be lonesome without her. Roy considers her as she bags his groceries.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'll see you tomorrow. (hesitates, then) It's Kathy, right? (off her nod) I'm Roy.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CHECK-OUT WOMAN)
dialogues.text: Hi, Roy. They shake. Two people meeting after seeing each other every day for months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy walks through the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before noon, the place is mostly deserted. One or two layovers at the bar and a custodian vacuuming the floors. Roy and Frank case the place. Roy, a standard-sized black briefcase beside him, withdraws a cigarette; Frank bums one from him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He said he wants to fly the money straight to the Caymans. Afraid he might get robbed.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: As if someone would do that. When's his flight? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 119 120 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 72a.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Friday. (beat) Where do you think? Roy points at...

dialogues.speaker: LEATHER BANQUETTE
dialogues.text: Roy sits facing the bar, against a wall, the standard- sized black briefcase beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You plant this before the meet. And keep the table free. I'm here, you sit him there, back to the bar. Otherwise we blow it off.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who's the drunk gonna be?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Ernie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Typecasting.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What do you expect for fifty bucks? Frank scans the place once more, a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: There's only one problem. (as Roy waits: what?) I think I'm in love with you. Frank lets out a whoop! He's going to be rich.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Roy stands alone in the middle of the lounge, looking from table to bar, then to all the walls. Running the plan over in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summer school lets out. Roy scours the young teens flooding from the school from his Caprice across the street. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 72B. CONTINUED: (Al) 120

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Perv. She's snuck up behind him. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: In the car. She gets in, looks at him, grins.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What would you like to do today, little girl?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Mom says I have to be back by dinner. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You'll be back by dinner. What would you like to do? She grins even wider. Roy blanches dramatically: Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh was right. Angela lifts a bowling ball up to her eyes, then lets it rip down an alley -- CRASH! Meanwhile, Roy cleans his ball meticulously with his handkerchief -- even the finger holes. It's his turn to bowl now and, with a swallow for courage, he plunges his fingers into the ball to pick it up. Angela passes him on the way back to her seat.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I own you. Roy glares at her, then steps up to the alley. Concentrates. Approaches and releases his first roll. Gutter ball. Keeping his chin high, he retreats to the ball return.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (approaching him gently) Dad. The first thing you have to understand about this game is: ninety-percent of it is knocking down at least one pin. He grabs at her, and she screams with laughter. And just then -- BEEP BEEP BEEP -- it's Roy's PAGER going off. He checks it, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You want me to bowl for you?

dialogues.speaker: AT PAY PHONE
dialogues.text: Roy thinks about wiping the receiver down, but his handkerchief has already gone dirtier places. Over the MUSIC and CRASHING PINS, he yells: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: B122
dialogues.text: 122 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 74.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: It's me, what is it? (beat) What?! I thought it wasn't ‘til Friday! (beat) Well, tell him -- Roy's face falls. Angela, bowling in the distance, rolls a strike and leaps in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's on a cellular headset, rubbing his temples, stressed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know, I know, he bumped it up. He says he won't be back for a month. (beat) I don't want to lose him, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Roy's stressed, too.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: There's no time. I gotta get the money, change, get Ernie... What time's his flight? Roy's face falls. Angela, bowling in the distance, rolls a strike and leaps in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy exits, in a rush, and Angela trudges out behind, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It just came up. I gotta take you home.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (it's not) It's okay. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 75.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I can't, uh, I just can't -- (looks at watch) I can't do this. There's no time. I can't even take you home.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (playing the victim) You want me to take the bus?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No. shit! He doesn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Is it a job? Roy nods.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (timidly) Can I help? Roy considers her, thinks, then:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Really? Roy nods, unhappily.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What do I get to do? Roy thinks. Is this the worst idea he's ever had?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, with standard-sized black briefcase, enters with Angela.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I thought you kept all your money in the horse. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 76.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That's just my piggy bank. Wait here. He heads downstairs. She follows, as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Angela approach the Clerk.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'd like access to my safe deposit box. J-215.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: (offering form) Signature and pass code, please. Roy starts to fill it out. Covers the pass code from Angela's prying eyes. In whispers:

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Why can't I see?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause it's a secret.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Then why does he get to? Roy thinks. To the Clerk:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Can I add an access signature to my account. The Clerk nods, puts forth another form. Roy pushes it toward Angela.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Sign here and here.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Do it. She does. Back to whispers:

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: So, what, now I can get into the whatever-it-is?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No. You don't have the pass code. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 76A.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: When do I get that?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: When I'm dead.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (forlorn) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Don't weep for me too much. Now wait here. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy opens his deposit box. Inside are bound, neat stacks of hundred dollar bills and hundred-pound notes, piled atop a fist-high ream of bonds. He starts picking up stacks of cash and placing them in the black briefcase. He closes the case, feels its weight. Then, to the guard around the corner:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Hey: you got today's Times?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy exits with Angela.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: How much is in there?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (re: briefcase) I told you.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (re: bank) No, in there. Three hundred thousand? He just smiles: not telling.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Five hundred thousand? A million? He shrugs. Angela is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: How did you --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I've been doing this a long time.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Why aren't you -- why don't you go live in Hawaii? Why don't you buy Hawaii?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I told you: I don't like the outdoors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy puts on his Arden glasses.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: These still make me look old?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Old and rich. Roy checks his watch. He's really not certain about this. 77. 126 127 (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 78.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You know what to do? (off her nod) You keep real far away from us. Anything seems off, you get outta there. You see me tug my tie like this, you get outta there. He gives her two hundreds from his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Take this. Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Stop worrying about me. I'm barely even doing anything. He gives the whole plan one more thought. Shakes his head. She looks at him with puppy eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Please, can I have the pass code? He has to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy enters, carrying the black briefcase, and immediately he spots a problem: Frank sits in the banquette seat Roy should have. Roy continues his approach, clasping his back now and wincing. Frank and Frechette greet him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Arden, you okay?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: My back. Strained it last night.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I told you: You should do yoga.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (a joke) I was doing yoga. You mind if I sit there. The high back helps. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 79.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank and Roy change seats, Roy sneaking a reproachful glance Frank's way: nice fucking job. As he sits, with difficulty:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How are both of you? Across the lounge, Angela peeks out from behind a partition to watch Roy, Frank and Chuck. A waitress delivers Roy a club soda and departs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: So: who goes first? Roy and Frechette face off: who will make the first move?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I suppose ladies do. The Queen before Ben Franklin. Roy lifts his black briefcase onto an empty chair between them and cracks it open just enough for Frechette to see: a newspaper. Frechette pries underneath: wall-to-wall British pounds inside.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: That's eighty thousand? It looks like less than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: It always does. Frechette reaches in to flip through a stack of bills: they're all real.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Sorry. Had to check.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: As long as you don't mind. Roy closes the case and sets it down on the floor by his feet. Meanwhile, Frechette replaces it with a gym bag. As he unzips it, Roy steals a glance at the lounge entrance: Angela is entering.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Do your worst. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 80.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy explores the gym bag: it's loaded with stacks of hundred dollar bills.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (to Frank) You count it? Frank nods. A pregnant pause. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: It looks like we have a trade.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: God bless America.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Land that I love. Roy salutes him with his soda, and Frank and Frechette raise their Scotches to toast --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Enjoy the Caymans. Don't get too much sun.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You kidding? He's going there for the shelter. Suddenly, from the bar:

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, come on! I'm twenty-one! Roy peers up and Frank and Frechette turn to look: Angela is screaming at the lounge bartender.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: My I.D. is in my luggage! My plane doesn't leave for thirty minutes! Can't I get a goddamn beer?! The bartender cautions her and she grabs a tumbler --

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You touch me, I'll break every glass in this place. -- then hurls the GLASS down at the floor, SHATTERING it, drawing every eye, including Frechette's, and that's when Roy pulls the switch: the briefcase stowed beneath the banquette for the identical one by his feet. Lightning fast. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 81.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Hey, you! Airport bartender! Angela backs out of the lounge, arms raised, giving the finger with both hands to the bartender. And she's gone. Frechette turns back, none the wiser. Frank knows, of course -- Angela's tantrum was part of the act -- and he looks at Roy incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Hope she isn't on my flight. Speaking of which: it's about that time. Who goes first?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You do. Just get up and take your new briefcase with you. When I leave, I'll take my new gym bag.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Simple is safe. Roy nods to his wisdom, then pushes the briefcase at his feet across to Frechette. Frechette picks it up, bids Frank and Roy farewell --

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Guys. Let's do it again some time.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Have a safe flight. -- and departs. Roy and Frank watch him go.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (under his breath) What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Go with him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That wasn't --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Walk him to the plane.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: They won't let me past the security check. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: A130
dialogues.text: 130 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 82.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Then walk him to the security check. Frank follows Roy's orders and chases after Frechette. Roy reaches under the banquette and grabs the briefcase there. A bag in one hand, the case in the other, he takes off in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy exits briskly, crossing to the parking garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy emerges from a stairwell and Angela leaps from behind a pillar to surprise him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Boo! Roy keeps walking, despite a minor cardiac, all business as Angela bounces around him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Did you see that old chick at the bar? With all the makeup? She almost died when I threw that glass.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I saw her.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What happened on our end? You take him? He nods.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: The whole eighty? Roy nods. Angela bounces higher, singing:

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: ‘My dad's a smooth operator! Smooth operator!’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Roy pulls out of his spot: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 130 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 83.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Dad, I thought about it: we should give the money back. I'd feel better. He looks at her, and she smiles: just joking. He's not in the mood.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Do I get a cut?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You can ask Frank for his. Roy stops behind a minivan pulling out of a spot, and he turns to see: -- the stairwell door fly open and Frechette appear, ina fury, suitcase open and empty, looking this way and that. He spots Roy instantly and starts toward him. Roy punches the gas, around the minivan and away.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (oblivious to Frechette) Dad?! Roy races down levels of parking lot as Frechette chases on foot. With a fair lead, the Caprice comes to four gated exit lanes, two cars in the three of them, one car in the fourth. Roy chooses that one.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (frightened now) Dad?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Roll up your window! Now! Get down on the floor! Angela does as she's told. His money ready, Roy waits for the car ahead of him to pass through, but the ATTENDANT seems to be taking forever to make change. Meanwhile, the other lanes are clearing up quickly. Roy considers backing up and choosing another exit, but the minivan he passed now hovers behind him. He's trapped. And Frechette appears in his sideview mirror, hustling toward him. At last, Roy pulls up to the parking Attendant, thrusts his money at her, then barks:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Open the gate, please. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 130 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 83A.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Do you need a receipt --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No! Please open the gate. The gate comes up, but too late. Frechette is upon them, on Angela's side, yanking on the door, rabid.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Dad! Roy hits the gas, and the Caprice slaps the gate as it rises, but before they're clear, Frechette gets a clean look at Angela hovering below the seat.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (slamming steering wheel) Dammit!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Are we okay? Roy looks down to her, balled up, shaking with fear. He has no one to blame for this but himself.  131 132 133 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dodgers are away, leaving acres of parking spots unused. Los Angeles looms in the distance. Frank paces beside his car and chain smokes as Roy's Caprice pulls up. Frank steps up to see Roy glowering at him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What? No reply. Roy just seethes.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Hiya, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (at a loss) Hiya. (back to glowering Roy) What?!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (to Angela) Stay in the car.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: But I want to --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Stay in the car! Roy gets out, slams the door, then reopens it, turns the RADIO ON to an EARSPLITTING VOLUME, slams the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela can't hear anything but MUSIC as Roy tears Frank a new one.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I said 'walk him to the plane.' Did you walk him to the plane?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I told you: security. They don't let you to the gate without a ticket -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Did you see him go through security?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Did you wait 'til the plane left the gate?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You told me to walk him there, I walked him there.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Frank, my daughter was there today! Frank looks away, chastened. Says something half under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm not the one who pimped her into the grift. And don't tell me I'm the one who put her at risk. She put us at risk.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What if he goes to the cops?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: He won't. They never do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What if he does?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Then he'd have to explain what he was doing with eighty grand and a ticket to the Caymans. (beat) We're not on the books. We're safe. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know we are. What about her?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Angela's never been arrested --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You don't know that. You don't know that! What if Chuck goes to the cops? Roy turns: Angela watches from inside the car. He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Turn it off. She does. Frank leers at Roy: ask her.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Tell him, Angela, and let's get this over with. Tell him you're clean. (beat) You've never been arrested, have you? Angela looks from Roy to Frank to Roy again. Then blushes. And bites her lip.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy hands Frank Frechette's bag of money, and Frank starts toward his car, and the younger man takes off. Roy leans against his hood as Angela remains in her seat.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I would have told you, but it never came up. Roy gives her the silent treatment a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You're fourteen! When did you have time to get arrested?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I forgot to pay for a pack of gum once, that's it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (disbelief) They called the cops on you for a pack of gum.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: And some other stuff. I mighta put up a fuss when security --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Angela...

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: The guard was groping me. He was grabbing at my chest, what was I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How long ago?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Last year.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: And they photographed you? They printed you? Angela nods and bows her head penitently. Roy, his hands slowly returning to his coat pockets, takes a stroll, super-pissed.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 136
dialogues.text: Roy drives, brow knit, thinking. Angela sneaks a glance at him, knows enough not to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's Caprice pulls to a stop, Heather's house in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy looks straight ahead, arctic. Angela tries to thaw him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You know, I have all of August off. I was thinking maybe I could come stay with you. He says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Or we could take a trip even. Oh, and in September is father's visiting day at school. It's kind of lame, but I thought maybe... Silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be gone for the next couple months. Frank and I have some out-of-town work. She nods, hurt but trying to conceal it. Tears form regardless.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: When do you think you'll be back?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Maybe when you get back --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (killing hope) You're getting in the way. Okay? I thought maybe it could work out, but it can't. Frank and I are partners. He wants you gone, you're gone. Angela's lip trembles and tears faucet down her cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Is it, did I -- Roy keeps staring straight ahead. Angela cries, elbows in her hands, arms clutching her gut.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I didn’t mean to... Roy, tortured, can't look at her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 138 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 89.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Can we at least talk on the phone? Roy says nothing. She weeps openly. Roy shrinks as he sees a woman dragging trash barrels to the curb. Mid- thirties, a faded beauty. HEATHER. He watches with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You wanna know why your mom left me? She left me because of you. So you wouldn't grow up with me as your dad. (beat) I am a bad guy. Roy can't stand this anymore. He leans over her and opens the passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: C'mon. Your mom'll be waiting. Angela wipes tears away. Anger supplanting grief. She digs into her backpack, withdraws an object wrapped in an "LA AIRPORT GIFT SHOP" bag, sets it on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I got it for you at the airport. (beat) I paid for it. She starts out of the car, but Roy doesn't want to let her go angry.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Ange -- She spins on him, furious, tears streaming.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Why did you even call me?! Why did you? Roy has no answer.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You're not a bad guy, you know. You're just not a very good one. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 138 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 B9A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She slams the door behind her. The interior light fades on Roy. He unwraps the gift shop bag: It's an "I Love LA" ashtray. FADE OUT.  139 140 141 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Roy's on the couch, arm thrown over his eyes. Hair unkempt, unshaven, wearing clothes for the third day in a row, the room around him a pigsty. Roy has let the place and himself go. The PHONE RINGS. And RINGS. And RINGS. At last, Roy picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Roy? You alright?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You hungry? He discards an empty can of tuna from the couch.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You wanna meet? We still got Chuck's money to split.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Almost three.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Hold on a sec. He hangs up. Doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also a mess. Roy rinses out a dirty coffee cup. Fills it with water. Watches it overflow. Reaches up to a cupboard for his pills. They're not there. Roy furrows his brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy looks inside his bedside table. Looks around it. They're not here either.  142 143 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scours his medicine cabinet, then inspects the waste basket, looks beneath the sink. The only thing here is one of Angela's barrettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes and backtracks through rooms, checking coat pockets in wardrobes, looking everywhere for his pills as he speaks on his portable phone:

dialogues.speaker: PHONE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Medical group.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Doctor Klein, please.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Dr. Klein is unavailable. Dr. Wiley is on call, if you'd like to --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I gotta talk to Klein. Is there a way of getting hold of him?

dialogues.speaker: PHONE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dr. Klein has gone for the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Where'd he go? Look, look: I need a new thing of pills. Are you there at the office now? Roy's PHONE BEEPS. He checks it.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Shit, my phone's dying.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sir, if this is an emergency, I recommend you contact a local hospital --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Listen: can you let me in his office -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PHONE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- sir, I can't --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: -- I know where he keeps them, or gimme Klein's home phone --

dialogues.speaker: PHONE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- Dr. Wiley is on call --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: -- I need to talk to Klein -- The phone dies --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Shit! -- and he hurls it against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy goes through the trash beneath his sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy at rock-bottom. He digs though his trash bin, then upends it. Cans and cans of Chicken-of-the-Sea rattle on the pavement. But no pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy presses his cheek against the floor mat of his car. He peers beneath the driver's seat, then reaches in and pats the floor, recovering -- -- one empty foil packet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Caprice swerves into traffic. Nearly forces several cars off the road. Surges ahead.  148 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Located in the rear of a discount drugstore. Five people stand on line for the white-coated, white-haired PHARMACIST. Roy joins the back of the line, wild-eyed, wild-haired, impatient.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: C'mon, c'mon. A few customers look back at Roy. He stares their glances away. Soon he can wait no longer. He pushes to the front of the line, empty packet in hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Hi, I need a refill of this. I don't have a prescription, but --

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Sir, please, wait your turn --

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I know, but this is an emergency !--

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN LINE
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy: ever hear of a line?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (turning) Ever been dragged onto the sidewalk and beaten till you piss blood? That decides it: nobody's screwing with Roy. The Pharmacist scans the horizon for security, doesn’t see anyone.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Please. I need a refill.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Do you have a prescription?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: My shrink, my doctor, he gave me these. They're samples of -- I can't remember -- Prefex- something.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Without a prescription!-- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Look: I have the packet --

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: I can't help you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: -- So I'm clearly allowed to have them. I just need four or five of these to cover the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: (resigning) Let me see it. The Pharmacist takes the empty packet from Roy. Studies it. Hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Those are vitamins.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: That packet contained vitamins.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No. My doctor gave it to me. Prefex...

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: They're vitamins, sir. Supplifen. Aisle four. Roy stands there, incredulous, infuriated. In aisle four, he rips open a box of Supplifen to find the replica of the packet he was given. He crushes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klein exits his sedan. Fumbling for his office key, he approaches the front door when Roy appears in the breezeway behind him, shoulders heaving, threatening. Klein gasps, startled, then:

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Roy? I'm not supposed to see you ‘till -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Vitamins. You gave me goddamn vitamins. Klein appraises Roy: he is not to be trifled with right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klein enters with Roy, turns on a light.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Would you like to sit?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I am sitting. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Roy: why do you think you need medication?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You are not asking questions yet. First you answer: did you give me vitamins?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Because you don’t need medication.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Look at me. I'm a mess.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Agreed. But you weren't a mess last week, and you weren't on Prefexall then either. (beat) I have news for you, Roy. Your neurosis is small-time. Your conscience is another story. (before Roy retorts) Let me ask a question. Does what you do make you happy? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A beat. 96. 150

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Don't change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: This is the subject. What would you do if you had to change careers?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: If I couldn't be an antiques broker?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: If you couldn't be a criminal. (beat) This is a 17th Century Williamsburg ottoman I've had my feet on for the last two months, Roy. I've had computer programmers tell me what a nice piece it is.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm not a criminal. I'ma con man.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: The difference being?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: They give me their money.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: That's a nice rationalization, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I never took anybody who didn't let me out of greed or weakness. I've never used violence.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Would you say then you set an example in your trade?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Sure. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 97.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: But now you have to set an example for someone else. (beat) How is she?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (beat) Angela? Fine. (as Klein waits him out) She wants back to her mom's.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Have you spoken to her? (as Roy shakes his head) Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Do we have to talk about this?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Why haven't you spoken?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (a beat) Because she hates me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Why do you think she hates you? Roy's face crumbles, and everything pours out:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Because I -- because I -- Oh, Christ, Doc! I lost my little girl! I lost my little girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank considers what Roy has told him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: As of now. Roy waits for Frank's reaction: is he pissed?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (he's not) You gotta do what you gotta do. I'm sorry to lose you. (beat) You want your forty g's?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Consider it a parting gift.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We should part more often.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Frank. For everything.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you, partner. They shake hands. Frank gestures to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is clean again. Roy opens a Radio Shack box, pulls out a new portable phone. Reads its instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy sits on his bed, phone in hand. Gathering his nerve. He twirls between his fingers the barrette he found in his bathroom. At last, he dials. One ring, two rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy sits waiting. Looks up as Angela approaches on her skateboard. Roy smiles. Angela does not.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: They walk along a path. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I went to see a lawyer. He specializes in custody suits, that sort of thing. Like when one parent wants to get joint custody of the child. (off no reaction from her) There are things you have to do. File paperwork, blood tests, go before a judge. It would only be for weekends and some holidays to start. Still no reaction.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'd have to make some changes. For one, I'm gonna have to stop doing what I do for a living. (as Angela stops, turns away) Honey, I'm sorry. I should have asked you first. She looks up at him, tears in her eyes, and throws her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Will you try? Please?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (soaring) Yes. I'll try, honey. I'1l try. He wraps his arms around her and holds her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Angela celebrate, Angela in a new-bought dress, which makes her fidget. A JAZZ COMBO PLAYS in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You know, I should talk to your mom about this. Let her know what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Your funeral. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I know. But she should hear it from me.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: We could get a dog. Either a German shepherd or a Lab.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (uneasily) They're messy, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Not if you train 'em. We can name it Frank.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That's a good name. They both smile. A WAITER pours Angela more Diet Coke.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle... Angela suppresses a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANCE FLOOR IN NEXT ROOM
dialogues.text: A few couples dance. Angela leads a reluctant Roy to the floor. She holds up her arms for him to take, and he balks.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Please... He gives in. Takes her hands in his and, very tentatively, begins to box-step. Concentrates mostly on his feet, then remembers to concentrate on Angela. And she, throughout, just beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. They enter, laughing. Angela is imitating the French Waiter as Roy fumbles the key out of the lock.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle... Bonjour, mademoiselle. O-reev-ar, mademoiselle... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Au revoir.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Au revoir. Au... Roy switches on a lamp, then leaps back: Chuck Frechette is sitting on his sofa. Cigarette in hand, handgun resting on the cushion beside him. Big smirk.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Hello, Roy. Hiya, sunshine. Roy freezes/considers the variables: the open door behind him, Angela before him.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Close the door. (as Roy hesitates) Close it. Roy considers Frechette's gun, does as he says. Angela trembles halfway between them.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Go wait in your room, honey.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Let her stay. She's in this as much as you are.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: What do you think? (to Angela) We haven't met, sweetie. My name's Chuck. It's Angela, right? (off no response) Your mug shot doesn't do you justice. (patting couch beside him) You wanna sit down? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy doesn' 102.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You come anywhere near her --

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Don't play tough, Roy. I'm in your home. I know where your kid lives. (back to Angela) You're a very clever girl. Tell me, can you spell 'shakedown'?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How'd you find me?

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: I didn't. I found her. In black and white. t understand.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Airport security cameras, Roy. They got a nice look at her. That was sloppy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: There were no cameras in the lounge.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: No. But there were in the gift shop. And suddenly it dawns on Roy, and his eyes drop down to the coffee table, to the "I Love LA" ashtray atop it. Angela's gift. Frechette extinguishes his cigarette in it. Frechette

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: In my business you need a few friends on the force. Your little girl's in their books. And your ex-wife doesn't know well enough not to give out your home address. (beat) Well, once I found you, sniffing out your buddy Frank wasn't such a big deal. indicates the corner of the room. There, Frank sits huddled, eyes puffed and blackening, nose bloodied, the crap kicked out of him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: We only hurt the ones we love, huh? Angela gasps. Frank meets Roy's stare with helpless, horrified eyes. Roy blanches.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: You look white as a ghost, Roy. I don't want you to pass out before you make your first payment. But first things first. Let's have back the money you took from me.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I don't have it.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Then let's start with what you do have. Again Roy eyes the gun, his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Four thousand. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (staring toward it) The horse.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: No. Let her get it. Roy stops. Angela looks up at him, frightened. He nods: it'll be okay. She moves toward the horse. Takes its head off, starts scooping out money.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: Next: I'm in for half of what you make from now on. Otherwise, I call those cop friends of mine, your little girl goes to juvie ‘til she's eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm out. I'm done with this. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: You're not done, Roy. You barely got your feet wet. Frank's not done -- are you, Frank? Frank doesn't say a word. His eyes are fixed on something. Frechette follows his stare to -- Angela, standing by the horse, Roy's .38 in her hands leveled at him. Everyone freezes, including Roy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Angela, put it down, honey. I'11l take care of this.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (fixed on Frechette, tears in her eyes) I want you to go.

dialogues.speaker: FRECHETTE
dialogues.text: You know how to use that thing, sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Put it down, Angela. Don't make it worse. Angela doesn't budge. A standstill. Then, a small voice behind her:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do it.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Quiet, Frank. Frank stumbles to his feet, aching, bloodthirsty. Frechette, frightened now, moves his hand toward his gun.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Don't. Frechette stops. Angela looks to Roy. All their dreams are slipping through their fingers. Roy holds her glance, apologizing for everything.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Daddy... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frechette reaches for his GUN again and -- pure reflex -- Angela FIRES -- BOOM! -- then drops the .38 to the floor. Roy turns. Frechette falls off the couch, blood seeping from his shirt. Shaking, voiceless.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Dad... Angela trembles, numb. Roy goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Frank: get his gun. Frank hobbles over to Frechette. Roy holds Angela.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Daddy...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: It's okay. It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Roy? He's not gonna make it. Roy looks over: Frechette is dying. Angela sees it, too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Roy? What are we going to do, Roy? Roy's got a lot of thinking to do very fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls Chuck's Mercedes up the driveway to the side door where Roy exits, holding a blanket over Angela's shoulders. He opens the passenger door for her and she gets in, nearly catatonic. Roy speaks past her to Frank:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You know where the Seven Palms Motel is?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Out the 15?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Get a room. Ground floor if you have to go out the back. And wait there for me. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Suppose you don't show?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Take her to her mother's. Then you drive south and never come back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then) Take him to a hospital. Frank realizes the risk Roy is running. Roy kneels beside Angela. He closes

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Angela. Angela? Frank's gonna get you out of here, and I will see you in a day or two. It's gonna be alright, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I... I was trying to...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I know. Honey, listen to me. You didn't shoot him. I did. Understand? I shot him. Right, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes, you did, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You just sit tight, honey. (as this could be good-bye for a while) I'm sorry I let you down. (to Frank) Go. the door. Holds eye contact with Angela as Frank reverses and carries her away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy opens a pantry closet, pulls down some sheets, then passes into --  160 161 162 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and his eyes stop at the bloodstain on the carpet. Frechette is gone. Roy drops the sheets, does a three- sixty, looking for places he might have crawled to. Nothing. He spins -- Frechette is leaning against the wall behind him, deathly pale, blood dripping down his legs. He lifts his gun up unsteadily, points it between Roy's eyes -- -- and Roy pivots away just as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An air-conditioner overhead; an I.V. in his arm; an admission bracelet around his wrist; a uniformed COP sitting in a chair; a surveillance camera above him.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: You awake? The Cop rises and goes out the door. Roy tries to lift himself onto one side, can't -- he's handcuffed to a bed railing. He pokes at a bandage wrapped around his head. He looks around the room: Spartan, antiseptic, an open door to a mini-bathroom. He is --

dialogues.speaker: IN HOSPITAL ROOM
dialogues.text: Tiny. One bed, no TV, bars on the windows. The door opens again, and two detectives (BISHOP and HOLT) come in, shutting the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Morning, Roy. How d'you feel? Roy tries to rise again, swoons.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Whoa. Take it slow.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Who are you? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 162 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 108.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: I'm Detective Bishop, this is Detective Holt. Doctor'1ll be in in a sec. Roy processes this, feels his bandage again. Bishop fishes in his jacket, pulls out an evidence bag containing a bullet fragment.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: You were given a pretty close haircut the other night, Roy. This little fella took out about half an inch of your skull. Bishop offers a couple of head X-rays. Roy can barely sit up much less study X-rays. Bishop drops them.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: You got lucky, Roy. Wish we could say the same for Chuck. Roy remembers slowly, wisely keeps his mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Am I under arrest?

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: (nods ) You have the right to remain silent. Anything you say can and may be used blah blah blah blah...

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: I heard it all.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Roy: where's Frank?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Who? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Frank Mercer. Your partner. We've spent the last couple days in your home and his. There's not a lot we don't know.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: I like your place better. Clean.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: You guys led interesting lives. In fact, there're some bunko cops eager to talk to you when we're done. (beat) Where is he, Roy? Roy shakes his head: he doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Okay. How about this: where's Angela? Roy stonewalls.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: She's not at your place, she's not in San Pedro at, uh --

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: (referring to notepad) -- 415 Chester Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Her mother's near hysterical. Roy reacts.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How long have I been here? (as they don't respond) How long?

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: They brought you in two nights ago. Roy thinks, then: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy nods. Holt goes 110.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I shot him. I shot Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: He was gonna shoot me.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: He did shoot you.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Before then.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: You're sure about that? Bishop and Holt exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: That would make our job a lot easier. Alas, the print we took off your .38 was a little small. (beat) Where is she, Roy? (beat) Your little girl killed a man, Roy. That's right. Chuckie didn't make it. to the window, yanks up the blinds. Roy winces in the glare.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Your daughter's wanted for murder. You're under arrest for accessory. It's not good, Roy. But it could still get worse. (beat) Where is she? Roy's mind races. Figuring some way to make this right again. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I wanna see my doctor.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Like I said, he'll be in in a sec. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No, my doctor. My shrink. Let me see him and I'll tell you whatever you want to know. Bishop and Holt exchange glances again.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: You know where she is? Roy nods. Bishop considers it.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: What's his number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy peers through the open blinds as an intern checks his vitals. From the bed, he can't see anything but a freeway in the distance. Bishop and Holt return with Dr. Klein in tow, a little agitated. The intern departs.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Hey, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Hello, Roy. (to Bishop) May I sit down? Bishop nods, and Klein takes a seat by the bed.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: How are you feeling? Roy looks. Bishop, Holt and the cop haven't moved.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Can we have a little privacy?

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: That's not how it works, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Don't I have doctor-patient rights or something? Holt laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Technically, he's right. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Technically, he's not. That refers to testimony you might give based on confidential information. There's no privilege says I gotta leave you two alone together.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You do if you want what I know. They stare each other down. Finally, Bishop relents.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Five minutes. They exit.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Roy, what happened? They told me -- Roy holds up his free hand: Don't speak ‘til they're gone. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: There isn't time, Doc. (beat) Can I trust you?

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Roy -- I can't do anything illegal. Roy glances up at the surveillance camera, then covers his mouth with his free hand, lest any lip readers are watching.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Angela's in trouble, Doc. If I don't help her, she will go to jail. Please. Help me help her. Klein looks reluctant. Roy's eyes plead.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You got her into this, too --

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Don't transfer responsibility, Roy. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Just make a phone call. Klein thinks, decides: okay.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: How are you at memorizing numbers?

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO FEED
dialogues.text: of Roy whispering to Dr. Klein through his fingers. Then...

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: smoking, watching the feed, stymied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through his fingers still, Roy whispers. Klein leans forward to hear:

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: The room of Mr. Cole.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: My partner will answer the phone. Ask to speak to Angela.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: What do I tell her?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Tell her -- tell Angela you have the pass code. Tell her to write it down.

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: This is what I have to memorize.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: They're going to search you on the way out. Klein nods: he's ready. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: 543-N7-942. Again: 543-N7-942. Say it back to me.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (eyes to camera) Doc...

dialogues.speaker: DR. KLEIN
dialogues.text: Sorry. (covering mouth) 543-N7-942.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Again.

dialogues.speaker: 543-N7-942.
dialogues.text: (to himself) 543-N7-942.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That's all you have to do, Doc. Klein nods, tense, memorizing. Roy lies back, exhausted but hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klein hurries to his sedan, fumbling with keys. As he pulls away, another car follows several seconds behind: Bishop at the wheel, Holt on the passenger side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy stirs awake, sweating heavily. The air conditioner is off. The room is dark. The chair where the uniformed cop sat is empty.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Yo! Hello! (off no response) Hey! Officer Maddox! (off no response) Could someone turn the A.C. back on?! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 170 171 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 115.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy reaches for a bedpan on the floor, to throw at the door, but something rattles within. Roy shakes it again, then pulls out: a handcuff key. Roy tries it on his restrained wrist: it's a fit. He releases himself, checks the door, then pulls his feet off the bed. For the first time in days, he stands, a little wobbly, in nothing but a hospital gown.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: as he quietly cracks open his hospital room door, and his eyes go wide. Dumbfounded, he moves down a brief hallway, peers into --

dialogues.speaker: ADJOINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Empty except for the surveillance monitor propped up on a chair. Coffee cups and newspapers litter the floor. Also there: Roy's pants, shirt, jacket and shoes, thrown in a pile in a corner. Roy pushes on, through an exit door and steps out onto --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blinding sunlight. Roy's hospital room resides within a mobile construction-site trailer anchored atop the five- story garage. A freeway passes in the distance. Roy can't believe it. He staggers around the trailer, to the roof's edge, and looks down. The parking structure overlooks a largely-deserted stretch of Los Angeles. Roy feels his bandage again. Starts to unwrap it. Then pulls it clean off. Gingerly feels about his skull. No stitches, no fracture, no bullet hole. Just one mother of a bruise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy jogs down the bottom ramp, belting his pants, shirt unbuttoned. He finds a pay phone, but its cord has been sliced. VOICE (V.O.over phone) Seven Palms Motel.  172 173 174 175 176 177 178 116.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: The room of Mr. Cole, please. C- O-L-E. (beat) How about Mercer? M-E-R... Bad news. Roy spots a cab, drops the phone to hail it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cab waiting, Roy finds the front door locked, finesses it open. As he enters, he notices Klein's plaque is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark, until Roy turns on an overhead light. The place is empty. Furniture and fixtures stripped, diplomas off the wall, cabinets bare. Roy squeezes his eyes shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM within the Caprice's window: Roy arrives in a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much as he left it. "Blood" stain on the carpet. The head of the ceramic horse beside it. Roy reaches within, extracts the only remaining item: a handwritten letter.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Roy: You're probably pretty upset. I don't blame you. You taught me most of what I know, so I suppose I owe you better than this.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy hurries in before it closes for the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy gives his pass code to the Clerk. He wears the same clothes and the same distant stare.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘But you always said if I gota shot at a big score, I should take it.’  179 180 181 182 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's box is removed. Large but no longer heavy. Roy touches his head wound.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Sorry about the rubber bullet, by the way. And for everything else.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy sets the box on a table, pries off the lid, revealing --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘If it's any consolation, you're the best I ever saw. I'd never find a better partner. Now I won't have to.' -- a single, thin stack of $100s.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Enjoy the gift. Frank.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLASTING UNDER a highway sign: "SAN PEDRO," then DOWN TO... Roy's Caprice, Roy at the wheel. All four windows rolled down, creating a windstorm inside his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, Roy parks in front of the house. He staggers to the front door and knocks, running on the slenderest of hopes. A moment passes before the door opens, and Heather stands before him. They share a long moment of recognition.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Roy... He looks numb, glass-eyed. He can barely speak.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: She's not here, is she? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 182 183 184 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 10/7/02 118.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Angela?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: (at a complete loss) Who? Roy, what are you talking about -- ?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: The baby! You were gonna have a baby! Heather is aghast.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: That's -- that's why you're here?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You were pregnant. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You were. Tears come to her eyes, too, a painful memory. His last hope dashed, all the revelations of the day come to a point, and Roy crumbles. He gasps for air, clutches his gut, and folds into himself.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Roy, Roy: you okay? Heather stands helpless before him, then slowly -- because of their history, or despite it -- reaches out and caresses him. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy on a smoke break. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 184 185 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 10/7/02 119-120.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His salesman's uniform is not terribly different from his old costume, and he still wears his hair in a completely unremarkable fashion, but his bearing has changed: he is aman at ease. A CO-WORKER sticks his head out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: CO-WORKER
dialogues.text: Roy: another live one. Roy nods, flings his cigarette away, returns to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy finds his next prospect: a twenty-year old SLACKER flipping through Persians.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Afternoon. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy turns. 121. 185

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: (keeps flipping) How ya doin'.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Help you with anything?

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: Yeah. I need a carpet.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: For your home?

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: For my secretary's office. (beat) No, it's for my apartment. All one room of it.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Big place, huh. You have a color in mind?

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: I have a price in mind. Cheap.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: So you don't need much, you don't know what you want, but -- no price is too low.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: That's about me.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You're my perfect customer. Let's dig into the remnants

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: Wait, I gotta wait. My girlfriend knows better than I do what we need. (off a DOOR CHIME) That's her. Angela enters the store. Looking nineteen at least. Dark glasses and cutoff jeans. She comes straight at her boyfriend, doesn't notice Roy at all.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What kind of pet store doesn't carry collars? They've got dog shampoo in there but no collars. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roy just stands there. Studying her. Making sure he's not mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: Then we'll go to another place. (to Roy) We just got a dog.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Let me guess. A Lab. She freezes, recognizing his voice. She won't turn to face him, while he keeps his eyes locked on her.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: Eh. German shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: My next guess.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: There's no special carpet that dogs like, is there? A beat. Will Roy say something?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: We call it Astroturf. C'mon, remnants are back of the store.

dialogues.speaker: IN BACK
dialogues.text: Roy watches Angela and her boyfriend flip through carpet fragments. Her attention is obviously divided.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: I like that... I like that...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You folks just move in together?

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: Three weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Big step.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: You think? We only started dating last month. If you're gonna get wet -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: -- might as well go swimming. The Slacker laughs: that's what he was going to say. Angela still won't face him.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: Ooh, I really like that one.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That's a nice choice. Durable. You barely notice stains it's so dark.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: How much is it?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Sticker's seventy-five. But I can knock off twenty percent if you pay cash. Angela and her boyfriend mull it over, under their breath then agree: it's a sale. Angela dips into her purse... He smirks

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: Our living arrangement. I pay the rent, she buys all the carpets.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Shit. I think I left my... yeah, I left my wallet in the car. (to her boyfriend, with a big sigh) Can you get it for me? It probably just fell under my seat. at Roy -- what can he say? -- and heads off.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: Be right back. Roy and Angela watch him go, alone together. She turns at last to face him. They lock eyes for a moment, then she indicates the cigarettes in his shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Can I bum one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy lights Angela's cigarette, then his own. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: When did you start smoking?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Long time ago. I was stealing from your pack the whole time. Surprised you didn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I was missing a lot back then.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You like this job?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) It's not that much different from the old one really. Steadier. Only been on it six months. They smoke in silence. What to say?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You working this guy?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Nah. I'm retired. That was a one-time deal.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No shit. You were good.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I had a good teacher. (sheepishly) Teachers.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm surprised to see you here. Figured you would have moved to, I don't know, Hawaii.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I had bills to pay. My mom was real sick.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: She get better? (as Angela shakes her head) I'm sorry. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, too. If it's any consolation. You mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You didn't take it. I gave it to you. She takes him in again: the new at-ease Roy.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Things are good with you, aren't they? SLAM! Angela's boyfriend exits the back door.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: There you are.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Just stealing a drag.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: (empty-handed) I looked everywhere. She pulls out her wallet.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I found it. Sorry. Her boyfriend gives her a look, and Angela gives him a big kiss for his effort. Roy looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy helps the Slacker load and tie his and Angela's new purchase onto the roof of their aging Honda Civic.

dialogues.speaker: SLACKER
dialogues.text: Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Enjoy it. The Slacker gets in. For a fleeting moment, Angela and Roy stand alone again before she gets in the car.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: It's good to see you, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Good to see you, too. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A beat. She starts to open the car door, stops.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You're not gonna ask my name?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I know your name.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (smiles) I'll see ya, Dad. Then hops in the car. Roy watches the carpet-loaded Civic pull creakily away. Looks up at the sun for a moment before heading back into work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy buys ice cream and frozen pizzas. A young man works the check-out register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving home. Windows down. Roy keeps just one hand on the wheel, only bringing the other up for a turn (when we might notice: he's wearing a ring).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy pulls his Caprice up the driveway and gets out. Groceries in hand, he heads to the front door, unlocks it, enters. Turning to look inside the house: THROUGH the front windows, for the first time open and unencumbered by shades: Roy walks into the living room. A new carpet replaces the old. He pays it no mind. He leafs through mail, calls out a name, then turns as -- -- Kathy enters from the kitchen, wiping her hands clean on a dishrag. She smiles and Roy smiles, too, explaining what he got at the market and opening his market bag wide for her to see. She rubs his head: nice job, then kisses him, and he kisses back -- -- and when they break, she whispers sweetly in his ear, and he smiles even more. He looks down to lay his palm gently on her belly. They go into dinner. FADE OUT.
